questiontext.text: If not done already, install the dslabs package from CRAN (use install.packages("dslabs")). Use View() or glimpse() to examine the gapminder data. Use ?gapminder to see a discription of this data. We want to investigate changes in fertility between the years 2008 and 1996 . Use filter() and pull() to make two vectors of the fertility values for these years. Note, the 185 countries will be in the same order in both vectors, so this is a paired test. Also note that the values won’t be normally distributed so we won’t use a t test. Calculate the Wilcoxon test statistic using wilcox.test() for the null hypothesis that the fertility from the year 2008 is the same as the fertility from the year 1996. Give your answer to three significant figures.

generalfeedback.text: Make the vectors using gapminder |> filter(year == 2008) |> pull(fertility) etc.Get the Wilcoxon test statistic using wilcox.test(x, y, paired = T, var.equal = T)$statistic.

questiontext.text: If not done already, install the dslabs package from CRAN (use install.packages("dslabs")). Use View() or glimpse() to examine the gapminder data. Use ?gapminder to see a discription of this data. We want to investigate changes in fertility between the years 1960 and 1984 . Use filter() and pull() to make two vectors of the fertility values for these years. Note, the 185 countries will be in the same order in both vectors, so this is a paired test. Also note that the values won’t be normally distributed so we won’t use a t test. Calculate the Wilcoxon test statistic using wilcox.test() for the null hypothesis that the fertility from the year 1960 is the same as the fertility from the year 1984. Give your answer to three significant figures.

generalfeedback.text: Make the vectors using gapminder |> filter(year == 1960) |> pull(fertility) etc.Get the Wilcoxon test statistic using wilcox.test(x, y, paired = T, var.equal = T)$statistic.
